This is mildly off-topic, and yet relevant...

I have some data I want to visualize.  The nature of the data is a network 
or mesh of associations.  It is far more complicated than the networks that 
NEAT generates.  Thus, the solution for visualizing this data might be a 
good way of visualizing a complex NEAT network, too.  So I thought perhaps 
the people on this list might have some interest in a contributing to a 
solution to this problem.

The origins of the data is the dictionary.  Specifically 
dictionary.reference.com and thesaurus.reference.com.

I started with a word.  It really doesn't matter which word, but I started 
with 'intelligence'.  I query the dictionary and thesaurus entries for that 
word and parse the results.  I get a list of words that appear in those two 
pages.  I save that list as the list of 'associations' for that word.  Now 
for each of those words (which I have not already processed), I repeat the 
process.  Virtually no matter what word I start with, I end up with 
basically the whole dictionary.  Then I prune those associations to include 
only those that are reciprocal.  That is, word A references B, and B also 
references A.  An example would be Tree and Bark.  This pruning makes the 
data SIGNIFICANTLY smaller, but still pretty large.

Now I would like to present the data as a visual 'mesh' or network.  It 
would help me to 'see' the connections.  I want to minimize the lengths of 
the connections so that related words appear close to one another.

Here's what I had in mind.  Load the data into memory.  Randomly assign x,y 
positions to each node.  Then treat every direct connection as an attractive 
force, and treat physical proximity as a repulsive force that falls off with 
the square of the distance.  For each time step, calculate the net force.  
Then reposition the nodes based on that net force.  Repeat until the net 
movement approaches zero.  Then save the positions of everything and 
generate a visualization of it.

For NEAT, I thought that you could add an additional 'force' that is an 
extra repulsive force between input and output nodes.  Then, the input nodes 
would tend to cluster towards one side, and the output nodes on the other, 
with a delicate balance forming in the nodes in between.

Any thoughts?

-- John





The data is a list of words (the whole dictionary), and what words are 
referenced by the lookup of that word.  That is, if you look up a word, you 
will get a return page.  On that page will be a number of words.  For each 
word on that page, I create an association or link between them.

I then pruned the list of links to only those that are reciprocal.  If I 
look up Tree, I might find Bark.  If I look up Bark, I will find Tree.  
Since the words that you get when you look up Tree includes Bark and vice 
versa, I save that 'connection' as an association.

Now I *know* that there are 'clusters' of words that are all interrelated.  
That is, groups of words that link to one another, even every member of the 
group.  What I would like to do is position the nodes such that the average 
distance between connections is minimized.

What I thought about doing was creating a model where the connections are 
treated like an attractive force, and where phisical proximity is a 
repulsive force, and then let the system relax itself, re-organizing the 
physical location according to the net force vectors and then repeating 
until the nodes settle down and the average net force is minimized.  By 
placing the nodes initially in a random dispersion, they should 
self-organize.

Anyone have any thoughts?

Now, I want to graph the result.
